fullProgramDescription: The Mathematics-Computer Science program is designed for students who are interested in the overlap between mathematics and computer science, including algorithm design, computational complexity, and scientific computing. The program provides a strong foundation in both mathematics and computer science, preparing students for a variety of careers in industry, government, and academia, as well as for graduate study in either field.
shortProgramDescription: The Mathematics-Computer Science B.S. program at UC San Diego combines mathematical rigor with computational theory and practice, preparing students for technical careers or graduate study.
classHighlights: The Mathematics-Computer Science program requires a foundation in calculus (MATH20A-B-C-D), linear algebra (MATH20F or MATH18), and differential equations (MATH20D or MATH21D).
Computer Science core courses include programming (CSE11 or CSE8A and CSE8B), data structures (CSE12), algorithms (CSE101), and computer architecture (CSE30 or CSE140).
Mathematics courses cover a range of topics, including real analysis (MATH140A-B-C), abstract algebra (MATH100 or103A-B-C), and probability and statistics (MATH180A-B-C).
Students also take advanced computer science electives, such as artificial intelligence (CSE151 or250A), computer networks (CSE123), or database systems (CSE132A-B).
Electives allow students to explore specialized areas, including machine learning, data science, computational complexity, or computational geometry.
learningOutcomes: Apply mathematical principles to the design and analysis of algorithms and computational systems.
Understand and implement fundamental data structures and algorithms.
Analyze and solve problems using computational methods.
Demonstrate a strong foundation in mathematical theories and models relevant to computer science.
Communicate complex mathematical and computational concepts effectively.
creditRequirements: 180-190 quarter units (varies depending on course choices and preparation)
additionalInformation: Students are advised to consult with departmental advisors to plan their course sequence and choose electives that align with their interests and career goals. Preparation in high school mathematics and computer programming is recommended.
